docs.lead_paragraph: A record number of trees are expected to fall victim to gypsy moth caterpillars this year, according to the New Jersey Department of Agriculture, which predicts that 200,000 to 300,000 acres of trees will be defoliated by the pesky creatures.

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors, pharmacists, and emergency room personnel may one day have instant access to the medical records of patients in New Jersey. The State Assembly passed a measure on Monday that would create an electronic database and infrastructure to share patient information, which supporters say would save more than $700 million by eliminating unnecessary paperwork, tests and administrative costs. ''We will never achieve anything close to universal access to health insurance unless we save the costs that can be saved in health care by reducing all the redundant studies that we do and reduce the costs of performing transactions in health care,'' said Dr. Herb Conaway, a Democratic assemblyman from Burlington who was one of the primary sponsors of the bill. Mr. Conaway, a practicing physician, said that he believes an electronic system is more efficient for both patients and doctors.

headline.main: Legislation Would Create Statewide Medical Database

docs.abstract: New Jersey State Assembly passes measure that would create electronic database and infrastructure to share patient information among doctors, pharmacists and emergency room personnel (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Colombia is set to become the first Latin American country to give established gay couples the same rights to health insurance, inheritance and social security benefits as heterosexual couples under a bill passed by Congress and expected to take effect soon. Some states and cities in Latin America, among them Mexico City and Buenos Aires, have passed similar laws, but no other country in the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic region has done so at a national level, said Marcela Sánchez of the gay rights group Colombia Diversa. Congress’s lower house passed the bill, 62 to 43, late Thursday. The Senate passed a similar version in April. The two chambers must now agree on a unified text before sending it to President Álvaro Uribe, who backs it.

headline.main: Colombia: Lawmakers Approve Gay Rights Bill
headline.print_headline: Colombia: Lawmakers Approve Gay Rights Bill
